top_comments_top.body:
Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.

The best time to plant a tree is 20 years ago 

The second best time is today

I am constantly blown away to learn that decently paid (6 figs or close) late 20s/early 30s folks at my job don’t take advantage of 6% 401k match. Many don’t even know about it because they don’t understand saving/investing and tune out at the benefits meeting every year.

People who say this sort of thing assume that a kid on a minimum wage job and a zero-hour contract actually has a reliable amount of surplus money each month to put into a pension plan. Quite often, its not even reliable to cover rent each month.
It feels so small & impossible... then 15 years go by and you feel great.  Just need to stay committed & not touch it.

top_comments_best.body:
Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.

The best time to plant a tree is 20 years ago 

The second best time is today

I am constantly blown away to learn that decently paid (6 figs or close) late 20s/early 30s folks at my job don’t take advantage of 6% 401k match. Many don’t even know about it because they don’t understand saving/investing and tune out at the benefits meeting every year.
What if you're self employed and no 401k? What route can you take?

I worked in finance for a large medical group. The group had a 100% match on ALL of the physicians contributions to their retirement plan. Only about 20% took advantage of it to contribute. I was told that was because of student loans and multiple ex-spouses sucking up a big chunk of the doc's income.
